author: enrique
pre_context: We gather epidemiological, surveillance, and administrative data, as well as information from published literature, for model calibration. This can be challenging during outbreaks of unknown pathogens like SARS in 2003 and the current COVID-19. To address this, we utilize improved inference methods and model fitting algorithms to reduce confidence intervals. Our fitting procedure, using Bayesian inference and the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm, successfully achieved this goal. Our baseline predictions for Hangzhou, based on randomly sampling the posterior distribution, provide prediction intervals. The parameter values and credible intervals are detailed in Table 1, with data from newly confirmed cases in Hangzhou from January 21 to February 4, 2020 taken into account. These projections reflect the potential epidemic in Hangzhou if further control measures post February 7, 2020, were not implemented. Figures 4(a) and (b) depict the estimated peak time and control reproduction number, R c, respectively.4 (c), we show the projected time course of newly confirmed cases in Hangzhou together with its 95% prediction interval. The fit of our model predictions and the newly-confirmed case data is shown for the period between January 21 to February 4 in Fig. 4 (d). Based on these projections, if the more restrictive control measures after February 7 in the city were not implemented, the most likely peak time would have occurred on February 27, 2020, with the 95% credible interval from February 24 - March 5.
post_context: with the first quantile 1.414 and the third quantile 1.979. According to our estimate, if strict quarantine measures were not implemented after February 7, the number of peak cases would reach around 120,000 and the outbreak in Hangzhou would continue until mid-May 2020.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Covasim is an agent-based model that simulates COVID-19 dynamics and interventions. The duration of symptoms and viral shedding in COVID-19 patients can vary greatly, with durations typically increasing with severity. Our model reflects this variability by assigning different recovery times for asymptomatic, mild, and severe cases. Critical cases may recover or lead to death, with the likelihood of death increasing with age. The transmission of the virus occurs when a susceptible individual comes into contact with an infectious individual, with a probability denoted as β. In a well-mixed population with an average of 20 contacts per day, a β value of 0.016 leads to a doubling time of 4-6 days and an R0 of 2.2-2.7. The specific value of β = 0.016 in Covasim was chosen based on data from Washington and Oregon states.However, this default value is too low for high-transmission contexts such as New York City or Lombardy [51], and may be too high for low-transmission contexts such as India's first wave [52]. Hence, this parameter must be calibrated by the user to match local epidemic data, as described in Section 2.6.8. If realistic network structure (i.e., households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) is included, the value of β depends on the contact type. Default transmission probabilities are roughly 0.050 per contact per day for households,
post_context: , and 0.005 for the community.These ratios were selected to align with existing research on time-use surveys and known contact types and to ensure a mean close to the default β value for a population. In the absence of interventions, transmission events are estimated to occur roughly 30% in households, 25% in workplaces, 15% in schools, and 30% in the community. Interventions like physical distancing can alter the value of β. Individual differences in disease severity, time spent in each state, and infectiousness are accounted for by modeling variations in viral load. Studies have shown that viral load peaks before symptom onset and then decreases. This model includes two stages of viral load, with the high stage set at twice the low stage and lasting 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days. Viral load values are drawn from a negative binomial distribution, with a mean of 1.0 and a shape parameter of 0.45. These viral loads are used to adjust the transmission probability on a daily basis. Fig 2 shows the viral load distribution for a sample of individuals based on default parameters.

Without interventions, for a typical transmission scenario, approximately 30% of transmission events occur in households, 25% in workplaces, 15% in schools, and 30% in the community. Interventions like physical distancing can alter the value of β. We also consider variations in disease severity, time spent in each disease state, and individual infectiousness, with differences in infectivity modeled using individual viral load. Studies have shown viral load peaks around symptom onset then decreases. Our model includes two stages of viral load: an early high stage lasting up to 4 days, followed by a longer low stage. The default viral load is based on a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape parameter 0.45, consistent with international estimates. author: enrique
pre_context: Therefore, the user must calibrate this parameter based on local epidemic data, as outlined in Section 2.6.8. If a realistic network structure is considered, the transmission probability value of β varies depending on the type of contact. Default transmission probabilities are approximately 0.050 for households, 0.010 for workplaces and schools, and 0.005 for the community, with relative weightings of 10:2:2:1 chosen for consistency with existing data. When considering age-based susceptibility and other factors, the distribution of transmission events in an unmitigated scenario is approximately 30% via households, 25% via workplaces, 15% via schools, and 30% via the community. Interventions, such as physical distancing, can also modify the value of β. Additionally, we account for variations in individual infectiousness by modeling differences in viral load.Several studies have found that viral load is highest around or slightly before symptom onset, and then falls monotonically [54– 58]. As a simple approximation to this viral time course, we model two stages of viral load: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. By default, we set the viral load of the high stage to be twice as high as the low stage and to last for either 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter. The default viral load for each agent is drawn from a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape
post_context: , which was the value most consistent with both international estimates [59,60] and fits to data in Washington state and Washington.The daily viral load is used to adjust the per-contact transmission probability (β) for an agent on a given day. Figure 2 displays viral loads for a representative sample of individuals using default parameter values. The distribution of transmissions by asymptomatic, presymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals can vary by location, with estimated proportions for Seattle provided in [25]. There is conflicting evidence on whether transmission is reduced if the infectious individual is asymptomatic [55]. Our default assumption is that it is not, but we include a parameter that can be adjusted as needed depending on the specific modeling scenario or context. It is worth noting that some studies have observed much lower rates of infectiousness for asymptomatic individuals [61].
